main event: Several sightings of a round and pear-shaped object emitting blue and yellow flame were reported over Medway, Maine on 19 July 1956. The object was described as being the size of a dime at arm's length with a tail two to three times larger than the object.
interesting points: The sightings were reported by multiple credible witnesses, including a retired pilot and a civilian officer of the 1125th PIAFB.
The object was observed to travel at a high speed from west to east, emitting a distinctive flame, and then subsequently flamed out twice.
Local police received reports of an unidentified flying object and a loud explosion, indicating a potentially related event.
Weather was reported to be clear on the day of the sightings, with no clouds and a slight northwest wind.
Astronomers in the area were to be checked for support of the hypothesis that the sightings were caused by a meteorite.
sighted object: One round and pear-shaped object emitting blue and yellow flame
witnesses: Civilian, a retired pilot, and a civilian officer of the 1125th PIAFB
